cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications: price determination, market structure, decision making by individuals and firms, public policy. NOTE: extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Microeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

For L0101, L0201, L0501, L2501 and L5101: Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. Learning is somewhat self-paced, although students will be required to 1) regularly submit assignments by announced due dates; and 2) attend one online tutorial session per week from a collection of scheduled sessions. Any software needs outside of Quercus access will be announced, please check back for updates.

For L0301 and L0401: Course content will be organized by topic and week. Topic modules containing pre-recorded lecture videos, online discussions, weekly homeworks and other asynchronous elements will be released according to the schedule. All assessments must be submitted by the announced due dates. There may be some online synchronous activities (e.g. problem solving) that will be scheduled closer to the start of the semester. Students are expected to have a working microphone and webcam to participate in these activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications: price determination, market structure, decision making by individuals and firms, public policy. NOTE: extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Microeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be posted as pre-recorded videos and can be completed asynchronously. We will hold tutorials live online at specific times. Tutorial attendance is required and associated with grades. You will choose your tutorial section on Quercus from a set of different day/time options at the start of the semester. During the week, we expect you to complete the readings, watch the videos, attend tutorials, work through the problem sets, take part in online discussions and, complete homeworks and assessments by their due dates.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications from a macroeconomic (economy-wide) perspective. Topics covered include international trade and finance, role of money and the banking system, monetary and fiscal policy. Note: graphical and quantitative analysis are used extensively.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
MCV4U (Calculus & Vectors) and MHF4U (Advanced Functions), or equivalent secondary school mathematics credits

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

ALL SECTIONS: Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. Learning is somewhat self-paced, although students will be required to 1) regularly submit assignments by announced due dates; and 2) attend one online tutorial session per week from a collection of scheduled sessions. Tutorial sign up will occur in Quercus at the beginning of the term. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Any software needs outside of Quercus access will be announced, please check back for updates.

cmCourseInfo.description: Fundamentals for consumers, businesses, citizens. Microeconomics focuses on cost/benefit analysis: gains from trade, price coordination, competition/monopoly, efficiency/equity tradeoffs, government/market failures, environmental policies, income/wealth distributions. Macroeconomics focuses on: GDP growth, unemployment, inflation, monetary/fiscal policies, business cycles, exchange rates, government deficits/debt, globalization. Emphasizes economic literacy, fewer mathematical tools than ECO101H1, ECO102H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Principles of Economics for Non-Specialists

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students should enrol in ONE tutorial section based on availability.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are delivered as online synchronous Zoom sessions (which will be recorded and available on Quercus). Tutorials are not required, and scheduling may change from the meeting schedule. Assignments use Pearson MyLab Economics and peerScholar software. These software requirements are UNCHANGED from previous (in-person) offerings of the course.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Aug 20, 2020: Section added

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of markets and prices. Determination of prices through the interaction of the basic economic units, the household as consumer and as supplier of inputs and the business firm as producer and as employer of inputs. The pricing system as the mechanism by which social decisions and allocation of goods are made in a market economy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Rotman Commerce students are not eligible to enrol in this course.

Delivery Instructions

For L0101/9101+0201/9201 only: Lectures will be a combination of pre-recorded videos and online synchronous sessions. Students need a computer or a tablet, reliable high-speed internet, and the ability to download and upload assignments by the deadlines. Tutorials and office hours will be online synchronous (live at specific times).

For L0301/9301 & L0401 & L5101/6101: This course contains both synchronous and asynchronous elements.  Lectures will be pre-recoreded and available asynchronously, while tutorials and office hours will be conducted synchronously.  Most course elements have some flexibility in the timing, but students are required to be regularly engaged with and participating in the course, and will need to complete assignments within specified deadlines.  Students will need access to a computer with reliable high-speed internet, and the ability to download and upload assignments by the deadlines.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Aug 20, 2020: Section added

cmCourseInfo.description: Theory of output, employment and the price level; techniques for achieving economic stability; central banking and Canadian financial institutions and markets; foreign exchange markets and the exchange rate. This course is not intended for students enrolled in the BCom program; please see ECO209Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory and Policy

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Rotman Commerce students are not eligible to enrol in this course.

Delivery Instructions

For L0101/9101+L0201/9201 only:

  • Lectures will be pre-recorded and made available asynchronously online for students in all sections.
  • The 9am-11am and 12pm-2pm time slots will be used for section-specific synchronous online Q&A sessions with the instructor.
  • The 6pm-8pm time slots will be used for section-specific synchronous online tutorials.
  • Students will be expected to watch recorded lectures and read material from the textbook and other sources before Q&A sessions and tutorials.
  • All course materials will be made available online in all sections and all assessments will take place online.
  • It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities, even for students enrolled in sections L0101 and L0201.

For L0301/9301 & L0401/9401 & L0501:

In all following elements, any platform or software, approved by the economics department might be used. 

  • Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • Tutorials will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.
  • The Instructor and TAs office hours (Question/Answer sessions) will be held online synchronously (live at specific times).
  • Term tests and assessments will be held online, generally between 2 to 3 hours per assessment, within 6 to 10-hour windows to accommodate different time zones.
  • There will also be online quizzes, generally between 2 to 3 hours per quiz, within three-day windows to complete.

cmCourseInfo.description: The use of microeconomics to analyze a variety of issues from marketing and finance to organizational structure. Consumer preferences and behaviour; demand, cost analysis and estimation; allocation of inputs, pricing and firm behaviour under perfect and imperfect competition; game theory and public policy, including competition policy. Business cases are used to connect theory and practice and to highlight differences and similarities between economics and accounting, marketing and finance. This course is restricted to students in the Commerce programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory and Applications (for Commerce)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students will need Excel (with add-ins to be announced in syllabus), "Word" (to write papers), "Powerpoint" to make slides, off-campus access to CHASS (for data), and ability to use Teams (or Quercus tools) to collaborate on papers and projects.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO200Y1 and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Microeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All sections of the course are taught jointly by Prof. Freitas & Blanchenay. Register for a section that fits your schedule. Required synchronous activities such as tests and participation will be held around scheduled class times. Pre-recorded lecture videos, online discussions, homeworks and other asynchronous elements will also be included. All assessments must be submitted by the announced due dates.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deals more rigorously and more mathematically with the topics included in ECO202Y1 and is intended primarily for students in certain Economics Specialist programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. Tutorials are delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need to own and be able to use Zoom, office software (MS office or equivalent), a printer/scanner, and equipment necessary to use Zoom (a computer, headphone, microphone, webcam, internet connection).

cmCourseInfo.description: Macroeconomic issues relevant for commerce students. Analytical tools are used to examine policy issues: Canadian government budgets, Bank of Canada monetary policy, exchange rate policy, foreign trade policy and government regulation of financial intermediaries. This course is restricted to students in the Commerce programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Macroeconomic Theory and Policy (for Commerce)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be a combination of online synchronous meetings during class time (which will be recorded) and pre-recorded lectures. You may expect required online engagement within the class meeting time: a mix of significant assessments, office hours, tutorials and lectures. Asynchronous engagement will be offered where possible to accommodate students in different time zones. All assessments must be submitted by the announced due dates.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to mathematical methods commonly used in economic theory. Topics include: multivariate calculus, concavity and convexity, unconstrained multivariate optimization, multivariate optimization subject to equality or inequality constraints and differential equations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mathematical Methods for Economic Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and available online asynchronously.  Tutorials will probably be delivered synchronously online in one of the timeslots assigned to the course, depending on the availability of the TA.  Each test will be given once, in one of the timeslots assigned to the course (M4-6 and R2-5), so students must be available for both of these timeslots.  For the tests, which may have an oral component, students will be required to have a microphone and a webcam.  This plan is accurate as of early August.  For updates, please see the instructor's website for the course.

courses.name: Introduction to Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Aug 20, 2020: Section added

cmCourseInfo.description: Numerical and graphical data description; data collection and sampling; probability; sampling distributions; statistical inference; hypothesis testing and estimation; simple and multiple regression analysis (extensive coverage). Learn how to analyze data and how to correctly interpret and explain results. Use Excel to analyze a wide variety of data and replicate tables and figures in economics research papers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: GGR270H1, PSY201H1, PSY202H1, SOC202H1, SOC252H1, STA220H1, STA221H1, STA248H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Register for a section that fits your schedule. You may expect required online engagement within the class meeting time: a mix of significant assessments, tutorials, and/or other synchronous participation. Pre-recorded lectures, some pre-recorded tutorials, some assessments, online discussion, and/or other elements may also allow for asynchronous engagement. All assessments must be submitted by the announced due dates. Students need a computer with a microphone and camera.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores unstructured data sources such as text files, webpages, weather data, social media posts, satellite imagery, and traffic data and how economists harness these types of data. It offers a practical introduction to: creating datasets from these types of sources (for example, via web scrapping and machine learning), linking data sources, and managing and visualizing these data (for example, via geospatial visualization).
cmCourseInfo.title: Data Tools for Economists

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online synchronous. Students need a computer, Python, a mic, and a camera. Tutorials and office hours will be online synchronized at a specific time. This course is project-based, and students should be able to submit their projects and assignments by due dates.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores unstructured data sources such as text files, webpages, weather data, social media posts, satellite imagery, and traffic data and how economists harness these types of data. It offers a practical introduction to: creating datasets from these types of sources (for example, via web scrapping and machine learning), linking data sources, and managing and visualizing these data (for example, via geospatial visualization).
cmCourseInfo.title: Data Tools for Economists

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online synchronous. Students need a computer, Python, a mic, and a camera. Tutorials and office hours will be online synchronized at a specific time. This course is project-based, and students should be able to submit their projects and assignments by due dates.

cmCourseInfo.description: A rigorous introduction to probability and mathematical statistics intended for students in Economics Specialist programs. Probability and estimation theory, sampling distributions, hypotheses testing, multiple regression analysis. Students will learn the tools used in economics and finance to model and address randomness and uncertainty.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations of Econometrics
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: STA237H1, STA238H1, STA247H1, STA248H1, STA255H1, STA257H1, STA261H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended primarily for students in the International Relations program. This course offers an introduction to the economic causes and consequences of international trade in goods, services, labour, innovation and capital. Attention will be devoted to the economic impact of policies that affect these flows, such as protectionism and outsourcing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Economics of Global Trade

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be a combination of online synchronous meetings during class time (which will be recorded) and pre-recorded lectures. You may expect required online engagement within the class meeting time: a mix of significant assessments, office hours, tutorials and lectures. Asynchronous engagement will be offered where possible to accommodate students in different time zones. All assessments must be submitted by the announced due dates.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended primarily for students in the International Relations program. The course serves as an introduction to some of the causes of differences in economic performance across countries and the impact of a variety of government policies, such as monetary and fiscal policy as well as exchange rate regimes, and how each of the three interact in response to changes in development, sovereign debt, monetary unions and financial crises.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Macroeconomics and Policies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be a combination of online synchronous meetings during class time (which will be recorded) and pre-recorded lectures. You may expect required online engagement within the class meeting time: a mix of significant assessments, office hours, tutorials and lectures. Asynchronous engagement will be offered where possible to accommodate students in different time zones. All assessments must be submitted by the announced due dates.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/academics/research-opportunities

cmCourseInfo.description: The quantitative analysis of firms' strategies in real-world industries, using tools from applied microeconomics and statistics. Topics include: studies of monopoly, oligopoly, imperfect competition, and the estimation of demand and cost functions that underpin these markets.
cmCourseInfo.title: Empirical Industrial Organization
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course demonstrates how a rigorous application of microeconomic techniques can inform our responses to various environmental problems. Topics may include: air and water pollution and renewable resource management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental Economics and Policies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course elements:  

In all following elements, any platform or software, approved by the economics department might be used.  

• Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.  

• Tutorials will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously.  

• The Instructor and TAs office hours (Question/Answer sessions) will be held online synchronously (live at specific times).  They will not be recorded.

• There might be (based on demand) weekly 1 to 2-hour live webinars to go over and summarize the prerecorded materials and answer the questions about the materials, at specific times during the day.   The recorded version will be available later online.  

• Assessments will be held online, generally between 2 to 3 hours per assessment, within a 6 to 10-hour window to accommodate different time zones.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys important features of energy markets and related environmental challenges. One of the central objectives is to provide an understanding of the key economic tools needed to analyse these markets. A related objective is the development of a framework for understanding the public discourse on energy and the environment. Topics include: the hydrocarbon economy (oil, natural gas and coal), electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, renewable energy, conservation, carbon taxes and ‘cap-and-trade’.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and the Environment
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course is delivered in a hybrid format, with online lectures and tutorials on Mondays during the 2-5 EDT time period.  Lectures and tutorials are recorded and posted so that those unable to attend online at the specified course times can view the recordings. There will be no in-person sessions.  

Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled Monday 2-5 time-slot.

You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.

cmCourseInfo.description:
Focuses on the core ideas and concepts of game theory and on applications of them in economics and other social sciences. Topics may include: oligopoly, electoral competition, the theory of public goods, voting theory, the free rider problem, repeated interaction, bargaining, evolutionary equilibrium, matching and auctions.

Note: This course cannot be taken as a substitute in programs that require ECO326H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Game Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lecture or tutorials will not be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials and lectures will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. Students will not be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law).
cmCourseInfo.title: Economic Analysis of Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be prerecorded and delivered online asynchronously and posted on the website, along with power point, cases, quizzes and materials relevant to the lecture during the week of the scheduled lectures.

 

Tutorial questions and solution outlines will be posted in advance of the Tutorials meeting times. Tutorial meetings will be conducted in person:

L0101/9101 Wednesdays - 1PM to 3PM at UC 140    

L0201/9201 Thursdays - 2PM to 4PM at BL 205   

 

Office Hours will be conducted over Bb Collaborate - Quercus. Evaluation will be a combination of Lecture Quizzes and Crowd Mark Tests.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: November 27, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: November 27, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: November 27, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: November 27, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: The practical application of microeconomic theory to common legal problems: torts, contracts, property and crime, and the limitations of economic analysis. No previous familiarity with the law is assumed. (This is an economic analysis of legal issues, not a course in law).
cmCourseInfo.title: Economic Analysis of Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

L0101 and L0201:

Lectures – Will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously and posted on the website, along with power point, cases and materials relevant to the lecture at the start of the week of the scheduled lectures.

Tutorials - Offered synchronously in Bb Collaborate - Quercus with tutorial questions and solution outlines posted in advance of the Tutorials meeting times.

Office Hours - Bb Collaborate - Quercus.

Evaluation will be a combination of Lecture Quizzes and Assignments on Quercus and Crowd Mark Tests.

 

L9101 and L9201:

Lectures – Will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously and posted on the website, along with power point, cases and materials relevant to the lecture at the start of the week of the scheduled lectures.

Tutorials – Asynchronous - Offered with tutorial questions and solution outlines posted at the start of the week of the scheduled lectures.

Office Hours - Bb Collaborate - Quercus.

Evaluation will be a combination of Lecture Quizzes and Assignments on Quercus and Crowd Mark Tests.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course applies the tools of economics - theoretical and empirical - to study Canada's historical growth experiences. Topics include: the variation in well-being among Indigenous peoples (both pre and post contact), migration and indentured servitude, colonial money, child labour and education, and the rise of factories. The impact of colonial institutions on Canada’s economic success is studied in a comparative context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Economic History prior to 1850

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be prerecorded and available asynchronously.  Tutorials are primarily for student presentations, which students will prerecord and upload to Quercus.   Students will need a computer with reliable high-speed Internet access and a microphone. A webcam will be useful, but is not strictly required. Assessments can be completed asynchronously (within given time windows).

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Canadian economic history between 1850 and 1960, with a focus on the debate over the ability of the market mechanism to optimize economic development. Topics covered include: tariff policies, Confederation, the transcontinental railroad, opening the West, the Great Depression, monetary policy and the Bank of Canada, regional growth and dominion-provincial relations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Economic History, 1850-1960

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Complete lecture notes will be posted before class.  Seminars take place in the first hour of the meeting times or during the Friday time period through online discussion groups. Lectures will be delivered through synchronous BbCollaborate during the second and thirds hours of the meeting schedule. The BbCollaborate lectures are recorded so that students can access them asynchronously if needed.   Assignments, included exams, occur online. Students need only have access to Quercus online at the UofT site, preferably with video and audio capability.

cmCourseInfo.description: A development of the microeconomic foundations of macroeconomic theory to expand students' analytic skills by constructing and solving macroeconomic models. Topics may include: dynamic choice, neoclassical growth theory, uncertainty and rational expectations, business cycles, as well as fiscal and monetary policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Economic Theory - Macro

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: Game theory and applications. Topics include: strategic and extensive games, with applications to economics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Microeconomics - Game Theory

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recorded lectures, some online async assignments, online sync midterms and final exam, and online sync tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: Ample empirical and experimental evidence suggests significant departures from classical assumptions of economic behaviour. For example, humans are neither always perfectly rational nor always self interested. This course describes systematic ways in which behaviour deviates from neoclassical assumptions, generating new, and hopefully more realistic behavioural assumptions that have broad empirical, theoretical and policy implications.
cmCourseInfo.title: Behavioural and Experimental Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Most course elements will be available asynchronously.  Lectures will be prerecorded and available asynchronously, but elements like office hours will be conducted synchronously.  Course activities will have some flexibility in timing, but will require regular and ongoing engagement and participation within specified time windows.  Students will need a computer with reliable high-speed Internet access, and the ability to download and upload assignments by the deadlines.

cmCourseInfo.description: A use of microeconomics to study the behaviour of the family, including marriage, divorce, intra-family allocations, investment in children and gender roles.
cmCourseInfo.title: Economics of the Family
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered using zoom at schedule hours. Lecture will be recorded and can be viewed later.

cmCourseInfo.description: Spatial economic theory and urban public policy: firms and individuals in partial and general equilibrium, land development and land-use controls, urban transportation, efficiency and equity in spending and taxing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class will be primarily online asynchronous, with synchronous online class discussions every two weeks and regular online office hours.  All assessments will be asynchronous.

courses.name: Labour Economics: Employment, Wages and Public Policy

cmCourseInfo.description: Using tools from microeconomic theory and statistics, this course introduces students to the study of labour markets, focusing on employment and wage determination, and the application of labour economics to public policy. Topics may include: labour supply, labour demand, estimating the impact of welfare programs, minimum wages, and other labour market interventions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Labour Economics: Employment, Wages and Public Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

TBD: see Economics Department webpage for information

Delivery Instructions

Weekly lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously.  Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings.  Class will meet synchronously online for all students at indicated times for discussion of lectures.  Friday tutorial will meet synchronously online.  It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: The Economic History of the 20th Century: Trade, Migration, Money and Finance before 1945

cmCourseInfo.description: Tailored to advanced students in Economics, Commerce, International Relations and History. The focus is on growth and fluctuations in Europe and North America between roughly 1870 and 1939, with a particular emphasis on international trade and payments, migration, investment, and monetary arrangements.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Economic History of the 20th Century: Trade, Migration, Money and Finance before 1945

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In-person lectures will be available to students in LEC0101 (Tuesdays 10-12), students in L9101 will live stream the lectures online synchronously, and lectures will be recorded for viewing (or re-viewing) by students any time, any place.  I also plan to hold occasional tutorials Wednesdays 1-2, following the same delivery formats.  Office hours will be strictly on-line (using Face Time, Zoom, etc.) by appointment.  Grades will be based on five take-home tests and three short essays.

courses.name: Twentieth Century Economic History: Institutions, Growth and Inequality

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Tailored to advanced students in Economics, Commerce, International Relations and History. The focus is on institutions, growth and inequality in countries across the world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Twentieth Century Economic History: Institutions, Growth and Inequality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Complete lecture notes will be posted before class.  Seminars take place in the first hour of the meeting times or during the Friday time period through online discussion groups. Lectures will be delivered through synchronous BbCollaborate during the second and thirds hours of the meeting schedule. The BbCollaborate lectures are recorded so that students can access them asynchronously if needed.   Assignments, included exams, occur online. Students need only have access to Quercus online at the UofT site, preferably with video and audio capability.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures and class slides will be available for students to view asynchronously. Office hours and tutorials will be used to address questions from students about lecture content, textbook material and assignments. Course assessments will be scheduled at times that are more flexible to suit students' personal schedules and the time zones where they are living. Students must have access to reliable high-speed internet and electricity and a dependable laptop or desktop computer (either a PC or a Mac) that has a working microphone.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the interaction of the monetary and banking sectors with financial markets and the broader economy. It builds especially on tools developed in intermediate macroeconomics, but also focuses on the institutional structure of the Canadian monetary sector, including the role and operation of the Bank of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Money, Banking and Financial Markets
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All lectures will be prerecorded.  Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously on the course website.  Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. All tests and quizzes during the term will be given during the tutorial times Friday 9-11 am. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses may be offered in one or more subjects each year. Students must meet the prerequisites announced by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See the Department of Economics website for details.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be recorded and posted online. Group discussions and quiz will be synchronous. Tutorials will be synchronous and online.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to economics of financial assets and financial markets. Topics: inter-temporal choice, expected utility theory, security valuation, selected asset pricing models, market efficiency, and the term structure of interest rates - essential materials for an understanding of the role and operation of financial markets.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use Quercus and Crowdmark.

cmCourseInfo.description: Agency and incomplete information problems inherent in financial transactions; the role of contractual arrangements in overcoming them. Financial constraints on investment decisions of firms; the financial system in economic growth; the legal system in the functioning of financial markets. A look at theoretical and empirical literature covering these issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Economics II: Corporate Finance

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lecture/tutorials will be available for students to view asynchronously. Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is required that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 2, 2020: Delivery Method changed

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 2, 2020: Delivery Method changed

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the causes and consequences of international trade. The first half develops traditional models of comparative advantage. The second half examines more recent theoretical and empirical work on trade & wages, the political economy of trade, outsourcing, and firm heterogeneity.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Trade Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. The course instructor and teaching assistants will hold synchronous office hours (Q&A sessions) online, and in-person should public health guidelines permit. Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. These instructions apply to all four sections of the course.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the causes and consequences of international trade. The first half develops traditional models of comparative advantage. The second half examines more recent theoretical and empirical work on trade & wages, the political economy of trade, outsourcing, and firm heterogeneity.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Trade Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The core material will be delivered asynchronously. Course time will be used for synchronous problem solving as well as supplementary material and discussion of current events.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Sep 1, 2020: new section added

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to open economy macroeconomics and international finance. The core objective of the course is to develop macroeconomic models of open economies that can be applied towards gaining an understanding of recent events such as US deficits, financial crises, China's exchange rate policy and the Euro.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Monetary Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics in Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: How multiple regression can be used to answer causal questions. Implications of, and how to interpret different model specifications and identification strategies. Students will read, critically evaluate and replicate existing research, and conduct their own original analyses. Statistical software STATA or R will be used.
cmCourseInfo.title: Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics in Practice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ECO351H1 (Special Topics in Economics: Applied Regression Analysis and Empirical Papers), offered in Fall 2016 and Winter 2017.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Register for a section that fits your schedule.

 Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously. Learning is self-paced, with a new topic each week. Tutorials, focussing on using Stata, are pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. 

Some assessed activities, such as virtual group discussions will also be scheduled during scheduled class times; depending on TA availability, some flexibility might be provided to students on extreme time differences but this is not guaranteed. 

Hands-on help (office hours/Stata help) will be delivered online per the meeting schedule, or in-person in small groups should public health guidelines permit.

courses.name: Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics in Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: How multiple regression can be used to answer causal questions. Implications of, and how to interpret different model specifications and identification strategies. Students will read, critically evaluate and replicate existing research, and conduct their own original analyses. Statistical software STATA or R will be used.
cmCourseInfo.title: Data Analysis and Applied Econometrics in Practice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ECO351H1 (Special Topics in Economics: Applied Regression Analysis and Empirical Papers), offered in Fall 2016 and Winter 2017.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials are made available weekly as pre-recorded videos. Activities such as Stata support is offered during class time (typically one of the 3hour slot.) Some activities may require group work with students scheduled in the same class time. Office hours may be scheduled outside of class meeting times.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to econometrics similar to ECO375H1, with greater focus on applications drawn from business and financial economics. The course is built around the statistical foundations and economic applications of the multiple regression model. Using statistical software, students will also learn how to conduct, present, and critique empirical research.
cmCourseInfo.title: Forecasting and Time Series Econometrics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures and tutorials will be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to econometrics. Statistical foundations and the interpretation of multiple regression models, with an emphasis on cross-sectional data. Application of regressions to a wide variety of economic questions and data sources, including the use of statistical software. Problems in the identification of causality, and an introduction to methods of addressing common statistical issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Econometrics I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All lectures will be recorded to allow for asynchronous attendance, but must be viewed in time to satisfy the weekly schedule. Any live components of the course (tutorials, etc.) will be scheduled according to the time slots indicated in the timetable. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to econometrics. Statistical foundations and the interpretation of multiple regression models, with an emphasis on cross-sectional data. Application of regressions to a wide variety of economic questions and data sources, including the use of statistical software. Problems in the identification of causality, and an introduction to methods of addressing common statistical issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Econometrics I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All lectures will be recorded to allow for asynchronous attendance, but must be viewed in time to satisfy the weekly schedule. Any live components of the course (tutorials, quizzes, tests, etc.) will be scheduled according to the time slots indicated on the timetable and students must be available at the times indicated on the timetable. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course in applied microeconomics is concerned with the functioning of markets and the behaviour of firms within these markets. The focus is on strategic relationships between organizations, including competitive relationships among firms in the same market and cooperative relationships between a firm and its suppliers and distributors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Markets, Competition, and Strategy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/academics/research-opportunities

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Oct 1, 2020: delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers basic issues in the theoretical and empirical evaluation of public policy. Sample topics include: income redistribution through taxation and the provision of social insurance and public goods, the mitigation of externalities, and welfare analysis in behavioural models.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Economic Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The lectures will be pre-recorded and the students will be required to watch them before coming to class. The live class time will be used to take up any questions the students have as well as to work on problem set questions.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores a variety of topics in health economics, providing students with an overview of current and historical institutional characteristics of the market for, and public policy towards, health care. Students will apply theoretical and empirical tools to current domestic and international issues in health policy. No previous background in health economics is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Health Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

All lectures will be recorded to allow for asynchronous attendance but must be viewed in time to satisfy the weekly schedule. Any live components of the course (tutorials, quizzes, tests, etc.) will be scheduled according to the time slots indicated on the timetable and students must be available at the times indicated on the timetable. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Topics in Development Economics and Policy

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers a variety of topics pertaining to economic development and associated policies. Depending on the course instructor, the focus may be on theories and policies related to poverty alleviation, human capital formation, financial markets, international trade, governance or economic growth.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Development Economics and Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

We will have regular lectures as usual, and regular office hours as usual, but everything will be online. Lectures will be on Zoom, lecture slides will be posted on Quercus.

courses.name: Topics in Development Economics and Policy

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers a variety of topics pertaining to economic development and associated policies. Depending on the course instructor, the focus may be on theories and policies related to poverty alleviation, human capital formation, financial markets, international trade, governance or economic growth.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Development Economics and Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered synchronously but recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Some of the assessments in the course will require participation from the students at the scheduled lecture time. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Competing Views in Macroeconomic Theory and Policy

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a systematic analysis of competing perspectives on key areas of macroeconomic theory and policy. Special attention paid to competing views regarding key fiscal, monetary, and trade policy issues as applied to Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Competing Views in Macroeconomic Theory and Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Office hours will be online synchronous. Students need a computer or a tablet, a Zoom account, and the ability to download and upload assignments by the deadlines.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides a general treatment of the economics of energy markets and the use of regulation in addressing environmental and other issues arising in these markets. A central theme is the search for an appropriate balance between market forces and regulatory/government intervention. Familiarity with tools of microeconomics and statistics/econometrics is essential. Topics include: oil, natural gas, coal and electricity markets, global warming and other externalities, networks, feed-in-tariffs, carbon taxes, ‘cap-and-trade’ and incentive regulation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Energy and Regulation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course is delivered in a hybrid format, with online lectures and tutorials on Mondays during the 2-5 EDT time period.  Lectures and tutorials are recorded and posted so that those unable to attend online at the specified course times can view the recordings. There will be no in-person sessions.  Tests are synchronous with all students writing at the same time during the scheduled Monday 2-5 time-slot. You must have access to a computer or a tablet with a reliable internet connection in order to participate, download and upload materials, watch posted videos and write tests at specified times.

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses may be offered in one or more subjects each year. Students must meet the prerequisites announced by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See the Department of Economics website for details.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Discussions and planning of the experiments will be either in-class or through online chat rooms and online submission of assignments. Students will have access to the experiments online. Part of the course evaluation will be based on feedback, quizzes and assignments that are based on class discussion and online activities (e.g. experiments).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces and critically assesses economic research that uses genetic, neuroscientific, and other biosocial data. We will address questions such as: what are the effects of brain neurochemistry on economic decision-making? What role do nature and nurture play in economic behaviour and outcomes? What can we learn from genoeconomics? What are the policy implications (or lack thereof) of related findings? No previous background in biology or genetics is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Economics and Biosocial Data
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ECO422H1 (Special Topics in Economics: Biology, Genetics and Economics), offered in Winter 2017.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course presents the theory and practice of market design, including matching markets and auctions. Sample topics include: school choice, kidney exchange, spectrum auctions, and keyword auctions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Market Design

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times.

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the price, distribution, and growth theories of major economic thinkers before 1870, from pre-classical contributions by Aristotle, Mercantilists, and Physiocrats to the classical authors Adam Smith, David Ricardo, T.R. Malthus, and Karl Marx.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Economic Thought

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lecture notes will be posted and lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, i.e., prior to the official lecture date. Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials and lecture discussion/office hours are delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need only have access to Quercus online at the UofT site, preferably with video and audio capability.

cmCourseInfo.description: Behavioural Economics is a relatively new field that incorporates insights gained from psychological, experimental and neuroscientific studies. Research methods adapted from behavioural economics are now being employed in virtually every field in economics. The course will cover the main themes in behavioural economics: individual choices under risk and uncertainty, reference-dependent choices, intertemporal preferences, other-regarding preferences, bounded rationality in individual and interactive decision-making, and the measurement of rationality and recovery of preferences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Behavioural Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/​ECO204Y1/​ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ECO422H1 (Special Topics in Economics: Topics in Behavioural Economics), offered in Winter 2018, Winter 2019, and Winter 2020.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students are expected to use a computer with microphone and camera in order to participate in required online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies the methods used in modern program evaluation and micro-econometrics to identify causal effects in the presence of potentially unobserved confounding factors. Covers a range of methods and designs, both experimental and quasi-experimental. There is a heavy emphasis on the application of these methods to a broad range of economic questions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Empirical Methods in Microeconomics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

We will have regular lectures as usual, and regular office hours as usual, but everything will be online. Lectures will be on Zoom, lecture slides will be posted on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced topics in public economics and economic analysis of Canadian public policy. Through a mix of lectures and independent research, students will acquire theoretical and empirical tools for public policy analysis. Topics may include: income inequality and redistribution; fiscal federalism; taxation of corporate profits; and policies to deal with public goods and externalities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Public Economics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ ECO204Y1/ ECO206Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); at least 1.0 FCE in ECO at the 300+ level.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course involves team-based independent research. The class will meet online weekly, and students will interact with other team members through break-out rooms and through other online team meetings they schedule themselves. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order
to participate in online activities.

courses.name: The Economics of Financial Risk Management

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: November 25, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended primarily for students in the Financial Economics specialist program and is not open to students in the BCom program. The role of risk management in both private and public sectors, a discussion of why firms and government should hedge financial risks; individual and social gains of financial risk management; identification and quantification of financial risks (including Value-at-Risk measures); how derivative securities can be used for financial risk management.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Economics of Financial Risk Management
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ACT349H1, RSM332H1, RSM333H1, RSM435H1, ECO460H5, ECO461H5

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be recorded and the scheduled time slot will be used for tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended primarily for students in the Financial Economics specialist program. An introduction to the econometrics used in empirical finance, with an emphasis on estimation and inference using computer based applications. Topics will include: parametric and nonparametric models of volatility, evaluation of asset pricing theories, and models for risk management and transactions data.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Econometrics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In person lectures will be recorded and subsequently made available.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course develops the tools used in empirical research in financial economics. Coverage may include: discrete choice models, duration models, instrumental variables, differences-in-differences, regression discontinuity, propensity score estimators, sample selection models and cumulative abnormal return calculation. Topics are drawn from: ownership structure, mergers and acquisitions, capital structure, payout policy, CEOs’ effect on the firm, executive compensation, insider trading, shareholder activism, and bank financing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Empirical Financial Economics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course will be taught online using a combination of live lectures and recordings. Some of the assessments in the course will require participation from the students at the scheduled time. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course builds on material covered in ECO208Y1, ECO325H1, and ECO374H1/ECO375H1. Students will increase their data literacy and learn to apply techniques to address policy issues. Topics covered: how monetary policy is conducted, ways in which central banks use general equilibrium models and basic techniques for predicting key macroeconomic variables. Students will follow current global issues and forecast how domestic and international events may alter the Bank of Canada's monetary policy in the short run.
cmCourseInfo.title: Empirical Macroeconomics and Policy
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
ECO325H1, ECO425H1, ECO475H1

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online as per the timetable meeting schedule. Discussion is an integral part of the course.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research-oriented course continuing from ECO375H. The regression model is extended in several possible directions: time series analysis; panel data techniques; instrumental variables; simultaneous equations; limited dependent variables. Students will complete a major empirical term paper, applying the tools of econometrics to a topic chosen by the student.
cmCourseInfo.title: Applied Econometrics II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO375H1(70%)/ECO374H1(80%), NOTE: STA302H1 is not accepted preparation.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures and tutorials will be available for students to view asynchronously. The course requires synchronous online presentations on Bb Collaborate or Zoom. In addition to computers, students need equipment such as microphones.

cmCourseInfo.description: Students will complete an original research paper on a topic of their choosing. Topic must be microeconomic and applied, meaning all papers will involve data and quantitative (regression) analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Honours Essay in Applied Microeconomics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ECO200Y1/ECO204Y1/ECO206Y1; ECO202Y1/ECO208Y1/ECO209Y1; ECO220Y1/ ECO227Y1/ (STA237H1, STA238H1)/ (STA247H1, STA248H1)/ (STA257H1, STA261H1); ECO372H1/ECO374H1/ECO375H1; 3.0 GPA in economics courses; approval of the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
ECO374H/ECO375H and ECO372H1

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To apply for ECO499H1Y, please email the Undergraduate Administrator at ugadministrator.economics@utoronto.ca with the following items: (1) A copy of your unofficial transcript (2) Briefly (in less than one page), please tell us: (a) Why do you want to take ECO499H1Y, and (b) any thoughts you have on the topic you are likely to choose for your original research paper. Please make sure to let us know if your topic is inspired by your previous coursework, and if you have already spoken to a member of the Economics Department about your ideas.

Delivery Instructions

Live or zoom at scheduled meeting times. Because this is a seminar, there is no self pacing.
